article.text: Wednesday 11 April 2012 10:29PM BST 10 Apr 2012 Annan's peace plan for Syria was not dead, but time was running out for the Syrian government to "The message to President Assad is, you haven't got much longer to implement the Annan plan and to show the world that you are serious at all about bringing an end to this situation," Mr Hague said. "So far, the Assad regime has used the time coming up to these deadlines to increase the violence and repression against the population of Syria," Damascus had agreed to a Security Council-backed Tuesday deadline to withdraw troops from Homs, Idlib and Deraa and stop using heavy weapons against the The Syrian government had also agreed to a full ceasefire by the army and rebels on Thursday morning. Kofi Annan visits Syrian refugees in Turkey Syrian army shell Hama on eve of ceasefire Syrians describe torture and executions Assad's adversaries likely to return to UN Security Council Assad 'will pay' for breaking peace pledge However, Syrian troops killed 31 people on Tuesday, pursuing a fierce assault on President Bashar al-Assad's opponents. William Hague said Britain would return to the UN Security Council if Kofi Annan's peace plan failed and also seek to get the Council to refer Syria to the International Criminal Court. "If the Annan plan isn't working, I believe it will be right to begin the process of referring Assad to the International Criminal Court, although that also requires the agreement of the Security Council, so is not a simple process," the Foreign Secretary said.
